Question: What is the reason for repeatedly extensively and concisely contemplating impure objects when cultivating this contemplation of impurity?
Answer: It is to show that the mind of contemplation attains mastery.
That is to say, one who attains mastery over objects
is able to repeatedly extensively and concisely contemplate them.
If one is not in control, one lacks this ability.
Furthermore, that yogin thinks like this:
From beginningless birth and death, my mind has been disturbed by afflictions, regarding the impure as pure.
Now, I contemplate impurity as it truly is.
I wish to perfect it by repeatedly extensively and concisely contemplating it.
Furthermore, it is to show the great power of wholesome roots.
The meaning is that I take a small impure characteristic and am able to gradually expand it to fill the entire earth.
Then I gradually reduce it to only contemplating a small part.
Isn't the power of the object great?
Moreover, the yogi himself manifests great power.
Therefore, he often observes the object broadly and briefly.
That is to say, from beginningless time, he has been grasped by the power of desire and greed,
and therefore he is unable to freely observe the impure object broadly or briefly.
Now, having subdued desire and greed, he has attained mastery,
and therefore he is able to often observe the impure object broadly and briefly.
Therefore, in this case, four sentences should be made.
There is impure observation whose object is small but not mastery is small.
That is to say, he only observes impurity in his own body.
There is impure observation whose mastery is small but not the object is small.
That is to say, he temporarily gives rise to the thought of impurity towards the vast earth, but is unable to observe it often.
There is impure observation whose object is small and also mastery is small.
That is to say, he temporarily gives rise to the thought of impurity towards his own body,
but is unable to observe it often.
There is impure observation whose object is not small and also mastery is not small.
That is, they are able to contemplate the impurity of the entire great earth.
There are also four sentences.
There is impurity contemplation whose object is immeasurable but not mastery is immeasurable.
This is the second sentence above.
There is impurity contemplation whose mastery is immeasurable but not the object is immeasurable.
This is the first sentence above.
There is impurity contemplation whose object is immeasurable and also mastery is immeasurable.
This is the fourth sentence above.
There is impurity contemplation that is neither whose object is immeasurable nor whose mastery is immeasurable.
This is the third sentence above.
When cultivating these three kinds of impurity contemplations,

Answer: For those who only enjoy brevity,

Starting from the bones, first observe the bones of the feet.
Explained in detail up to later observing the skull.
Again, in this, remove half and observe half.
Remove one part again.
Only observe one part.

Having observed these impure characteristics with the power of resolve,
Fix the mind between the eyebrows, and remain still.
Again, turn this thought and enter the mindfulness of the body.

Only those who delight in the extensive,
From going to the charnel ground, observing the characteristics of the corpse's bluish-blackness, etc., explained in detail up to gradually abbreviating,
Up to only observing one's own skeleton.

From going to the charnel ground and observing the characteristics of a dead body such as bluish-black, speaking in detail up to counting again and again, broadly and briefly.
Like before, observe.

Turning to the end, later observing the skull.

There is an explanation that only those who enjoy brevity

Question: What is the intrinsic nature of the contemplation of impurity?
Answer: It has the wholesome root of non-greed as its intrinsic nature.
The meditators say:
It has wisdom as its intrinsic nature.
Why is it so?
Because the sutras are the standard.
As a sutra says:
Having seen forms with the eyes, one contemplates impurity.
Contemplating in accordance with principle, and so on at length.
Because contemplation is wisdom.
Other masters say:
It has disgust as its intrinsic nature.
Why is it so?
Because it takes disgust as its object.
The judges say:
This contemplation of impurity
has the wholesome root of non-greed as its intrinsic nature.
It is neither wisdom nor disgust.
Why is it so?
Because it is the antidote to greed.
Question: How can the previous sutra be understood?
Answer: Because it is associated with wisdom, it is called contemplation.
However, its essence is the wholesome root of non-greed.
Because it is the proximate antidote to craving for form.
If it is together with its retinue, it has the essence of either four or five aggregates.
This contemplation of impurity
In terms of realms, it exists only in the desire realm and the form realm.
Because in the formless realm there is no contemplation of impurity that takes form as its object.
In terms of stages, it exists in ten stages.
This is because it exists in the intermediate dhyana of the desire realm, and in the four dhyanas and four preliminary concentrations of the form realm.
In terms of support, it only relies on a body in the desire realm.
Because the bodies in the form and formless realms do not give rise to this contemplation.
In terms of aspects, it is not the sixteen aspects. In terms of objects, it only takes the form base of the desire realm as its object.
Question: Does this contemplation of impurity take the entire form base of the desire realm as its object?
Or does it take a part of it?
Answer: It takes the entire form base of the desire realm as its object.
Question: If that is so,ğŸ”½how can the sutras be understood?
As a sutra says:
Venerable Asvaghoá¹£a was sitting in meditation under a tree in a forest.
After the first watch of the night, there were four celestial maidens,
all named Rati.
They were upright and extremely beautiful.
They came to the front of Venerable Asvaghoá¹£a's seat,
joined their palms in respect, and bowed at his feet.
They then withdrew and stood to one side.
They said to the Venerable One:
We four celestial maidens
can transform at will in four places.
First, we can transform into various supreme and wonderful forms that others find attractive.
We can all amuse ourselves and serve you.
Second, we can transform at will into various supreme and wonderful garments.
Third, we can transform at will into various wonderful ornaments.
Fourth, we can transform at will into various supreme and wonderful flowers, fragrances, food and drink, precious playthings, and all the pleasures we desire.
Venerable One, can you accept us?
At that time, the Venerable One had this thought:
These four have come here to see me and disturb me.
I will contemplate impurity towards them.
Having contemplated thus, he entered the first meditation but was unable to arouse it.
He gradually entered the fourth meditation but was also unable to arouse it.
He then thought,
These four celestial maidens have various colors.
Therefore I am unable to contemplate them as impure.
If they were to make themselves a single color,
I would definitely be able to contemplate them as impure.
He then told them,
Sisters,
can you all manifest blue bodies for me?
At that time, the celestial maidens manifested blue bodies,
but the Venerable One was still unable to contemplate them as impure.
He had them manifest yellow and red, but he was still unable to do so.
He then thought,ğŸ”½If they were to make themselves white, it would accord with the contemplation of skeletons.
If they can further manifest a white color,
I will definitely be able to contemplate them as impure.
He then told them, Sisters, change your bodies to white for me.
They immediately changed,
but he was still unable to contemplate them as impure.
Because the forms and colors of the celestial maidens are fresh and pure, like wonderful light, it is difficult to arouse disgust towards them.
Question: Why did Venerable Aniruddha cause the celestial maidens to transform into the four colors of blue, yellow, red, and white?
Answer: Because he wanted to observe the signs of the transformation and decay of the colors.
Moreover, because the transformation of the color characteristics easily arouses disgust.ğŸ”½Moreover, the blue color accords with the thought of blue and swollen,
the yellow color accords with the thought of pus and swelling,
the red color accords with the thought of difference from red,
and the white color accords with the thought of skeleton.
Moreover, blue, yellow, red, and white are the basis of various colors.
Moreover, because there is no dispute, he caused the transformation.
He tested his own mind to see if he could arouse disgust.
Venerable Aniruddha knew that their colors were wonderful.
He was unable to observe them and arouse the thought of impurity.
He then closed his eyes and sat in silence.
They knew that Venerable Aniruddha had no defiled thoughts at all.
They were ashamed and bowed at his feet, suddenly disappearing.
It is like two strong men who, when they grapple, know that their strength is equal and so they release each other.
You should understand that the case of the celestial maiden is similar.
If this is so, how can it be said that the contemplation of impurity can take all forms in the realm of desire as objects?
Answer: The celestial maiden cannot universally arouse the idea of impurity toward all forms in the realm of desire.
Since others can, there is no contradiction.
Because the Buddha, pratyekabuddhas, and Å›rÄvakas with sharp faculties can all contemplate it.
Question: Can one arouse the contemplation of impurity toward the Buddhaâ€™s physical body?
Some say:
There is no one who can do this.
Because the Buddhaâ€™s physical body is subtle, most pure, and extremely clean, like pure light, and cannot be despised.
Other masters say:
The Buddha can himself arouse the contemplation of impurity.
Others cannot do this.
Or some say:
The contemplation of impurity is of two kinds.
The first is that which arises from the characteristics of form.
The second is that which arises from the faults of form.
That which arises from the characteristics of form
can take the Buddhaâ€™s body as its object.
As for the faults of form,
one is unable to take the Buddha as the object.
Furthermore, there are those who say,
there are two kinds of impurity meditation.
The first is the object of common characteristics,
and the second is the object of specific characteristics.
The object of common characteristics is able to take the Buddha's body as the object,
while the object of specific characteristics is unable to take the Buddha as the object.
As for this impurity meditation,
it is associated with the mindfulness of the body.
Some say,
this is not the fundamental mindfulness,
but it can be the preparatory stage of the mindfulness of the body.
As for wisdom,
it is associated with conventional wisdom.
As for samÄdhi,
it is not associated with samÄdhi.
As for the faculties with which it is associated,
it is generally said to be associated with only three faculties,
namely, joy, pleasure, and equanimity.
As for the past, future, and present,
it belongs to the three time periods.
The past takes the past as its object,
the present takes the present as its object,
and the future that is about to arise takes the future as its object.
If it is a future dharma that is not about to arise, it takes the three time periods as its object.
As for wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate,
These wholesome [attitudes] are of three kinds.
As for whether they are bound or unbound,
they are bound to the desire and form realms, and take as their object what is bound to the desire realm, what is learned, what is unlearned, and what is neither learned nor unlearned.
They are neither learned nor unlearned, and take as their object what is neither learned nor unlearned.
As for whether they are eliminated by seeing or by cultivation, or are not to be eliminated,
they are eliminated by cultivation.
As for whether they take as their object names or meanings,
they only take as their object meanings.
As for whether they take as their object one's own continuum, another's continuum, or no continuum,
they take as their object one's own and others' continuums.
As for whether they are attained through application, through detachment, or through birth,
some are attained through application and through detachment.
They are not attained through birth.ğŸ”½As for those attained through detachment,
they are cultivated at the time of detachment.ğŸ”½As for those attained through application,
they are present through the application of effort.
The Buddha has no application.
The solitary realizers have lesser application.
The hearers may have middling application,
or superior application.
The ordinary beings have superior application that is present.
As for those that have been obtained and those that have not been obtained,
they are both those that have been obtained and those that have not been obtained.
The noble ones and bodhisattvas in their final existence are both those that have been obtained and those that have not been obtained.
The other ordinary beings are only those that have been obtained.
As for those accomplished through hearing, thinking, and cultivation,
they are all three kinds.
As for those in the mental faculty and the five sense consciousnesses,
they are only in the mental faculty.
Question: If that is so,
how can the sutras be understood? As a sutra says:
Having seen forms with the eyes, one contemplates impurity and properly contemplates in accordance with reality,
and so on at length.
Answer: The five consciousnesses serve as a gateway to give rise to the mental consciousness, which gives rise to the contemplation of impurity.
Therefore it is said, but the contemplation of impurity is only in the mental consciousness.
Just as the applications of mindfulness are only in the mental faculty, they are also given rise to by the five consciousnesses.
A sutra also says: Having seen forms with the eyes,
and so on at length, up to having cognized dharmas with the mind,
one gives rise to the six applications of mindfulness of joy, sorrow, and equanimity.
This is also like that.
Question: Does this impurity meditation also take sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas as objects?
Answer: It only takes form as its object, not the other five.
Question: If so,ğŸ”½how can the sutras be understood?
As a sutra says:
Having seen forms with the eyes,
... up to ... having cognized dharmas with the mind,
one contemplates impurity according to reality.
Answer: Because impurity meditation is brought about through the six consciousnesses,
it is said like this.
However, impurity meditation takes form as its object, not the others.
Furthermore, it is said like this based on the general antidote.
That is to say, although impurity meditation only takes form as its object,
it can counteract craving for the six sense objects.
Just as those who are covered by craving for form
subdue it by cultivating impurity meditation,
those who are covered by craving for sound and so forth
also subdue it by cultivating this meditation.
Therefore it is said like this.
Furthermore, having first given rise to impurity meditation on the form realm,
one becomes disgusted with all forms.
Later, one is also able to detest the five objects such as form and sound that rely on them.

Although detesting sound and so forth is a different contemplation, it is not not a contemplation of impurity. Because it is produced by the contemplation of impurity, it is called the contemplation of impurity.
Furthermore, having first contemplated the sense base of form and cultivated the contemplation of impurity to perfection,
later one also wishes to detest the other objects.
If one is able to, it is good.
If one is unable, one again contemplates the sense base of form and gives rise to the contemplation of impurity.
It is like when one first sets up camp before going out to battle.
If one is victorious, it is good.
If one is not victorious, one returns to the camp.
This is also like that, and therefore it is said.
However, the contemplation of impurity takes form as its object, not the others.
Furthermore, one first gives rise to the contemplation of impurity with regard to the sense base of form.
Later, with regard to sound and so forth, one gives rise to other contemplations of detesting.
That and this contemplation have the same mode of detesting.
Therefore, they are also said to be the contemplation of impurity.
Furthermore, the contemplation of impurity is of two kinds: first, the fundamental;
second, the outflow.
If it is fundamental,
it only takes form as its object.
If it is a natural outflow,
it generally takes sound, etc., up to impure mind and mental factors as its objects.
Because the Abhidharma only discusses the fundamental impurity meditation, it is said to take form as its object.
Because the sutras generally discuss the fundamental and natural outflow impurity meditations,
it is said that after seeing form, and so on up to knowing dharmas with the mind,
one contemplates impurity and properly reflects on it.
Question: Who can give rise to this impurity meditation?
Answer: Both noble ones and ordinary beings can both manifest it.
Noble ones can manifest it in all stages of learning and no-learning.
Question: Where does this impurity meditation arise?
Answer: Only humans in the three continents can first manifest it.
Because the six desire heavens do not have the characteristics of bluish-black, etc., they can only manifest it later.
Some say:
The first and last are only in the human realm.
Because the six desire heavens do not have the characteristics of impurity such as bluish-black, etc., they do not manifest it at all.
Question: In contemplating a dwelling place, bones fill it.
What is the object of this impurity contemplation?
Some say:
It takes one's own bones, etc. as its object. Other masters say:
It takes the bones, etc. seen in the charnel ground as its object.
Or some say:
It takes the empty space-element color in the dwelling place as its object. The commentator says:
It should be said:
This is associated with the intention of conceptual imagination and non-greed.
There is no fault in taking whatever one wishes as the object.
Question: This contemplation is not all bones, etc.ğŸ”½How can it be non-inverted?
Answer: This is wholesome,
because it is produced by proper attention,
because non-greed is its intrinsic nature,
because it leads to the superior practice of the noble path,
because it subdues the afflictions,
and because it produces a beloved result.
Although it is not in accordance with reality, it is not inverted.
Some say:
This impurity contemplation is also called inverted.
Because it views what is not impure as impure.
Question: If that is so,
why is it not unwholesome?
Answer: It is called unwholesome due to two reasons:
First, the object is inverted;
Second, the nature is inverted.
This impure contemplation, although the object is inverted, is not inverted in nature, and therefore is not unwholesome.
Furthermore, it is called unwholesome due to two reasons:
